section.title: Intro
section.para: If you are using the the Eclipse Jubula Feature in your Eclipse installation, you can start AUTs from within Eclipse, similar to the way in which you would debug an application using Eclipse. This section describes how to start your AUT directly from the IDE.

section.title: Requirements
section.para: The following Features need to be installed in order to start Swing AUTs:

listitem.para: Jubula Launch Support for Java / Swing

section.para: The following Features need to be installed in order to start RCP AUTs:

listitem.para: Jubula Launch Support for Eclipse RCP

para.para: You can find an update site containing the Jubula Feature and the Launch Integration in the correct version for each standalone version in the installation directory in the development folder.

section.title: Customizing the Perspective
section.para: In most cases, the button to start AUTs is not included in the main toolbar. The following steps describe how to add this button to a Perspectiveâ€™s toolbar:

listitem.para:
Select:
Window-->Customize Perspective...
from the main menu.
In the dialog that appears, select the Command Groups Availability tab.
Ensure that the entry Start AUT in the section Available command groups: is checked.
Close the dialog by pressing the OK button.

section.para: Once you have completed the steps listed above, the Start AUT button should be visible in the main toolbar of the active Perspective.

section.title: Starting the AUT
section.para: The Start AUT button can be used, just like the Run or Debug buttons, to launch an application or configure application launches. Applications started in this way are always started in debug mode. Furthermore, Start AUT adds additional information to the launch process, allowing the started application to be tested.
Some of the additional information that makes the started application testable can be configured from the Test tab of the Start AUT Configurations dialog.
The AUT ID can be assigned or left blank. If left blank, the configuration name (ex. New_configuration) will be used.

section.title: AUT Agent
section.para: Although the automatic AUT Agent selection generally selects the correct AUT Agent, it can be useful to know what criteria go into the selection process. These rules are followed when deciding with which AUT Agent the starting AUT should be registered:

listitem.para: If the ITE is currently connected to an AUT Agent, then that AUT Agent will be used.
If an embedded AUT Agent is running, the ITE will connect to the embedded AUT Agent and use that for AUT registration.
An embedded AUT Agent will be started, and the connection will be made and used for AUT registration.

section.title: Keyboard Layout
section.para: The Keyboard Layout for the AUT can be defined in the Start AUT Configurations dialog. The entered value must represent a locale and must represent a defined keyboard layout.

section.title: RCP Remote Control Plug-in
section.para: In order to start an RCP AUT, the RCP Remote Control plug-in (org.eclipse.jubula.rc.rcp) must be included in the launch configuration. The list of plug-ins for the launch configuration can be viewed and modified from the Plug-ins tab of the Start AUT Configurations dialog when an Eclipse Application launch configuration is selected.

listitem.para: Breakpoints may alter the timing of tests. This can have consequences such as timeouts, tests failing when they should succeed, and tests succeeding when they should fail.
Actions that affect the lifecycle of the AUT such as restarting it cannot be used in tests that use an AUT started via a launch configuration.
